document.docTitle: Limnostatua lewisi Souma & Ishikawa 2022, comb. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the tingine genera Cysteochila, Hurdchila, Physatocheila, and Xynotingis from Japan, with description of a new genus (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Tingidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of the tingine genera Cysteochila, Hurdchila, Physatocheila, and Xynotingis from Japan, with description of a new genus (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Tingidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Leptodictya?
lewisi Scott, 1880: 314
. Holotype : macropterous ♂ , Japan ; BMNH.

Cysteochila vota Drake, 1948b: 7
. Holotype : macropterous ♀ , Japan : Moji [= Kyushu, Fukuoka-ken, Kitakyushu-shi, Moji-ku] ( Fig. 7 ); USNM.
New subjective synonym.

Cochlochila lewisi : Drake & Ruhoff (1961: 150)
(new combination);
Drake & Ruhoff (1965a: 120)
(catalog).

Hurdchila lewisi : Péricart (1985c: 170)
(new combination);
Péricart & Golub (1996: 42)
(checklist: Palaearctic); Yamada & Tomokuni (2012: 197) (monograph); Yamada & Ishikawa (2016: 431) (checklist: Japan ).

Cysteochila consueta
(non Drake, 1948):
Hayashi & Higashikawa (1997: 36)
(distribution). Misidentification.

Three specimens collected from Honshu in 1995 have been recorded as
Cysteochila consueta
by Hayashi & Higashikawa (1997)
.

Diagnosis. Recognized by the characters of
Limnostatua
gen. nov.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4. Habitus images of
Limnostatua lewisi
comb. nov.
from Japan. Dried specimen, dorsal, dorsolateral and lateral views (A–C). Ventral structures: rostrum (D), male terminalia (E) and female terminalia (F). Scale bars: A–C, 1.0 mm; D–F, 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Fifth instar nymph. General color pale brown; compound eyes light red ( Fig. 5A–C ). Body oval in shape, 2.4–2.5 mm in length; dorsum with countless granular projections on surface. Head with five spines. Antennae smooth on surface, covered with minute pubescence; segments I separated from each other at their bases; segment II shortest among antennal segments; segment III longest among antennal segments; segment IV longer than segment I. Rostrum reaching posterior margin of mesosternum. Pronotum with two pairs of minute spines along midline; anterior pair on anterior part of pronotum and posterior pair on middle part of pronotum; outer margin with four spines. Mesonotum with a pair of minute spines on posterior part; mesonotal wing pad reaching middle part of abdominal tergite IV, with four spines on outer margin. Metanotum with a pair of minute spines on posterior part; metanotal wing pad concealed by mesonotal wing pad throughout their length. Legs smooth on surface, longer than rostrum, covered with minute pubescence. Abdomen longer than combined length of head and thorax except mesonotal wing pad; tergite I with a pair of minute spines on posterior part; tergites II, V, VI and VIII with a single spine along midline; tergites IV–IX with a pair of spines on posterolateral angles.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. Fifth instar nymph of
Limnostatua lewisi
comb. nov.
from Japan. Dried specimen, dorsal, dorsolateral and lateral views (A–C). Scale bar: 1.0 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Based on a comparison of
L. lewisi
comb nov.
and
C. vota
using the photographs of holotypes (https://data.nhm.ac.uk/object/1b6b587e-f044-4b9b-9b75-8e8eecc0d7f5/1582761600000; Fig. 7 ), original descriptions ( Scott 1880 : Drake 1948b ), redescription ( Péricart 1985c ), and a number of Japanese specimens, no morphological differences were observed between the two species. Therefore, the new subjective synonymy,
Limnostatua lewisi ( Scott, 1880 )
comb. nov.
=
Cysteochila vota Drake, 1948
,
syn. nov.
, is proposed. The holotype of
C . vota
syn. nov.
was collected from “ Japan : Moji” [= Japan : Kyushu, Fukuoka-ken, Kitakyushu-shi, Moji-ku] ( Drake 1948b ) ( Fig. 7 ).

Limnostatua lewisi
comb. nov.
was recorded as
C. chiniana
(=
P. chiniana
comb. nov.
) by Hayashi & Higashikawa (1997) . However, the former can be easily distinguished from the latter by the following characteristics: hood semi-globose, higher than pronotal disc at highest part ( Fig. 4A–C ); paranotum forming a dome opening inward; outer margin of paranotum resting on pronotal disc at anterior and posterior ends; costal area of hemelytron with 2 rows of areolae in middle part and in a single row in remaining parts; subcostal area subhorizontal: metasternum wider than mesosternum ( Fig. 4D ); and metasternal laminae curved outward.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6. Living adults (A, B) and a living fifth instar nymph (C) of
Limnostatua lewisi
comb. nov.
from Kanagawa, Honshu, Japan (photographs taken indoors). Host plant (
Persicaria sagittata
(L.) H.Gross) (D) of
L . lewisi
comb. nov.
at Kanagawa, Honshu, Japan.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Japan ( Hokkaido , Honshu, Kyushu, Tsushima Island), China , Korea .

In Japan ,
L. lewisi
comb. nov.
was found inhabiting marshlands in a temperate climate (cf. Yamada & Tomokuni 2012; Maehara 2014 ; Yamada & Ishikawa 2016; Nakatani 2019 ).

Host plant. In Japan , adults and nymphs were collected from
Persicaria sagittata
(L.) H.Gross ( Polygonaceae ) ( Fig. 6D ) at Honshu ( Maehara 2014 ; present study) and from
Clematis apiifolia DC. var. apiifolia
( Ranunculaceae ) on Tsushima Island ( Miyamoto 1976 ).

A number of individuals of
L. lewisi
comb. nov.
were collected from unidentified herbaceous vines in China ( Drake & Maa 1953 ).
Biology. Adults and nymphs were collected from the above-mentioned host plants in two botanical families, suggesting that the species is euryphagous.

Although many tingids typically feed on the underside of the leaves of host plants ( Schuh & Weirauch 2020 ), a number of individuals of
L . lewisi
comb. nov.
were collected from achenes of the host plant
Persicaria sagittata
in October at Honshu ( Maehara 2014 ). Additionally, nymphs were observed feeding on the achenes and peduncles of this polygonaceous plant in captivity (present study). Therefore, this species appears to feed on achenes and peduncles.
